transport.comment: An average 1.0m x 1.7m (3' x 5' roughly) solar panel generates 0.240kW, while the electric motor of a Nissan Leaf tops out at 80kW.  Here in Nova Scotia that panel would receive about 3.5 sun-hours daily, delivering 0.84kWh per day to the battery.  Lets say you drive the Leaf on the highway and while cruising at 100km/h (about 65mph) you're using 60% of the potential electric motor output (48kW).  The charge from the sun allows you to drive for 57 seconds and you'd cover 1.6 kilometers.

transport.comment:
>...if the effect of that regulation is to ensure that energy companies and not taxpayers bear the cost of that risk isn't that a good thing?

I didn't say regulation isn't necessary.  What we have, though, is strangulation wearing a regulation costume.  The executive order banning breeder reactors is a prime example.

>I just have a tough time imagining that it can outcompete solar if we're not socializing the cost of its risk. Solar is just so much simpler by comparison - throw a bunch of mirrors out in the desert and we're set.

Sorry, but solar only provides power for maybe 1/3rd of the day.  To make solar competitive with nuclear requires a secondary energy storage system that is far more expensive than the solar panels themselves.

>Electrified roads would be great, but tremendously expensive, and we'll need EVs that can use them before they make sense.

The prototypes being built use induction, IIRC.  It is true that they would be expensive, but they may be able to function as distribution lines as well.

>SkyTran or similar sounds great too, but convincing Americans to abandon their cars and use public transportation of any kind will always be a big challenge.

All it would take is one major city to deploy it.  The speed of getting to one's destination compared to cars would go a very long way to ending that American love affair with cars.

>I don't know why the Civic CNG remains the only production car out there available to go that route.

I'm confused by this as well.

>It's cheap and plentiful now, but eventually it'll have its supply problems too, so it can't be a long term solution like EVs can.

It will outlast oil by a couple of decades, so considering the longevity of cars, that is really not much of an issue.  One thing to consider with EVs is that they require a very petroleum intensive road system, just like other cars.

>Whoever said anything about doing that?

What almost always follows talk of the negative externalities of oil: taxation.

>...and EVs allow for access to this cheaper form of transportation energy.

Yet the price premium of the vehicles negates the cost of cheaper fuel.  This is even more true in the secondary (used) market.

>Phasing out per manufacturer effectively puts those companies who assumed the risk to invest in EVs early on at a huge competitive disadvantage should another company decide to jump in later.

They should have first mover advantage and various intellectual property from related R&D, though.  I do agree that phasing out by manufacturer makes no sense.

>I pointed out above that the only CNG car out there isn't that cheap.

That is really because of lack of availability.  There are lots of CNG cars in other countries.  If whatever is preventing them from being sold here changes, I expect the price will drop quickly.

My response to part 2 will have to happen much later today due to time constraints.

transport.comment:
Rebates on leases go to the dealership, so they take it off the value of the car. 

Personally, I'd grab a late model used Leaf. It's already depreciated in a massive way, so you'll be looking at owning a car that's pretty close to the same functionality at about half the price, and in a year or two, you can probably sell it or trade it in for most of what you paid for it. 

Do the math on your charging situation. If you can get access to a standard 110v plug, you can charge the car overnight with the trickle charger to recover about 40 miles of range in 10 hours. Same goes for plugging in at work. If you can do it, then you don't have to worry about charging at home. Those public Level 2 chargers can get expensive if you have those at work since they charge by the hour that you're connected, and not actual charging time. When you're full, you're still paying if you forget to go move your car. 

Definitely make sure it has a quick charge port. Level 3 charging is where it's at if you need a quick fill. Keep in mind, that you don't need to "fill the tank" on an EV as much as just get enough in there to get to your next charger. If you have one at home or work, then you can just quick charge for a few minutes to get the mileage you need to get where you're going since your car will be sitting there all night plugged in anyway.

transport.comment:
[If you look at the EPA fuel efficiency numbers for EVs](http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=35120&id=38170&id=37067&id=33905) you will see that many of the hatchback type vehicles get very good city mpge numbers, which helps boost their combined range number, but their highway mpge is 15-20% worse due to poor aerodynamics at high speed. 

On the other hand, when you look at vehicles that have been optimized for aerodynamics like the Tesla Model S you can see that **it gets better mpge numbers on the highway**. This is good because interstate travel between cities is where range is more important for most people.

If we look at the [238 miles of rated range for the Bolt based on the Spark EV city/highway efficiency it appears that its highway range will end up being around 218 miles.](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PAO9S2odYlYmMDDrWYaidc_T-3iZlTH_f_ob1EbloHQ/edit?usp=sharing) 

When you consider that the EPA highway test is based on a maximum speed of 65mph, but many states have increased speed limits to 70-75mph it appears that the Tesla Model 3 may offer real world range on par or better than the Bolt even if its combined EPA rated range is lower.

transport.comment:
It's not about just being less efficient per unit of energy, it's offering less for the same price. More energy also means more performance and being able to use faster charging standards. It's OK to get less range if you have more performance, I get it. But nobody is offering that. How likely is it that Mercedes electric SUV will have less than 3 seconds from 0 to 100 kmph? I'm skeptical.

Now, they could go the quality route and say that the materials they use are better and pay more attention to the fit and finish, which is fine but it's difficult to justify a higher price even then given you receive a less luxurious experience when you have to wait double or more to recharge an even less range capable battery pack. I mean where's the VIP experience in all that? Nowhere to be found.

Now if they adopted the 350 kW CCS standard they have been talking about and started to roll out a network of 350 kW capable charging stations, that would go a long way. They're not doing that, it will likely be 2020 and they will still be just preparing for it.

transport.comment:
The first thing you should do is determine how old your roof is. 

If you have a three tab roof and your roof is 10 years old then I would change it in advance if you are anywhere in the south.    If your roof is 10 years old and it’s an architectural roof then you might be OK but understand you might spend thousands down the road when you need the solar panels removed to fix your roof.      In the end it is probably just easier to replace your roof now and then put solar panels on because you don’t have to worry about anything Down the road for a long time.  

You could also just replace the roof sections where the panels would be on but I don’t like this method as your roofs well age different and then you have to deal with the headache of having roofers come out twice. Also if you just do the whole house at once you’ll probably get a much better price in the end. If you really want solar and want to 30 or 26% tax credit, then this is a route you could take. 

 If you have a brand new roof then get three local quotes. I would recommend someone that is using a high quality name brand because they have more of a chance to be around down the road.

transport.comment:
> My understanding is that there is no connection between the ICE and the drivetrain.

That's a common misconception.  [Here](https://www.gm-volt.com/threads/gen-2-volt-transmission-operating-modes-explained.337644/) description of the Gen1 and Gen2 voltec transmissions.  You can find the missing pictures [here](https://www.gm-volt.com/attachments/slide21-jpg.168446/) and [here](https://www.gm-volt.com/attachments/slide31-jpg.164350/)

Couple points:

* The Volt transmission is designed to run indefinitely on battery power.  If you simply deleted the gas tank, it would be a pure BEV with no compromise in performance.
* It *can* run as a series hybrid like a BMW i3, but it usually doesn't.  Why? because it is *more efficient to transfer power mechanically*.  
* There is an SAE paper where GM engineers demonstrate that, in terms of power transmission efficiency, fixed-ratio > eCVT > motor-generator.  In fact, when designing an eCVT, engineers try to optimize things so that as little power as possible goes through the electric path (but some power always has to be converted to electricity and back in a pure eCVT).
* In the Gen 2 Volt transmission, they added a mode with a single fixed-ratio that is even more efficient (for the speeds and engine loads where it is appropriate).  In that mode, 100% of power is transmitted mechanically.

Having owned a Gen 1 Volt, I think GM did a really good job--the engineering is really solid.  But I also believe they lost a ton of money on each one sold.

transport.comment:
Posts like this are helpful for people considering buying their first EV, so hopefully this saves someone some hassle! While I agree with the sentiment to plan how you'll charge before buying an EV, the extent of that planning other comments are describing is wild. 

When someone is choosing their next ICE car, do they think about downloading 5 apps and staking out charging stations at various times of day for 3 months before buying? Heck no. What person, who is wholly unfamiliar with EVs and how they work, is going to go to all that effort? If they don't realize they should? It's hard enough just trying to figure out how long different cars take to charge.

I own my home, I live in a multifamily building, in a city, and have neighbors in my building with chargers installed in their parking spaces, so I assumed I'd be able to do that also. I also checked all the charging stations near me to find out how many were withing walking distance and their pricing. I didn't consider availability (most are constantly in use) or hours of operation (most close by midnight). So, thinking I'd be able to charge at home soon, and in the meantime use public chargers, I went ahead and bought my car. I thought I was being a little neurotic with the amount of planning I was already doing. 😂

Then once I bought my car, I learned it would cost $7k to install my own charger at home, plus about $100/mo for electricity with vendor markup. Versus walking a few blocks away to charge for $30/mo and zero installation costs. It's annoying and I regret not knowing this before getting into it.

There are about 50 EVs for every 1 public charger in my city. That tells me the vast majority of people aren't using public chargers as their sole method of charging. We need L2 curbside charging, subsidies to install chargers in existing multifamily buildings, and building codes that require 100% of new of parking spots to have charging infrastructure in place.

1 & 2)My location is in Highland, Illinois. They city itself offer's it's own power: http://highlandil.gov/Public_Documents/HighlandIL_LightPower/index

3) I do have an online monitoring system. I have a SMA sunnyboy converter in my basement along with a sma webconnect box. I'm waiting for my RS485 comm card to come in; as that is what is needed to push data from the inverter to the webconnect. (whole other issue in itself but think i got it figured out).

My thoughts on this was say if I produce 20kw a day (some days that's what my inverter shows depending weather) if I only use 10 then. It would be nice to have access to that other 10 at night while the house is not producing. And in the instant where I would produce more then I used then its fine but just let my bill be $0 or something along those lines.

I also called the electric company and it is showing that I have used 374kwh this month.(~28 days since last reading) I'm betting since this meter is not bi-directional that alot of them kwh are from night and when the system is not producing as it seems i'm only getting to take advantage of my solar panels during the day when they are producing... like Rocksteady2R mentioned in the response above.

Also is there any truth to this?

*If the meter isn't a Net-Meter. It works like a Kill-A-Watt meter.
Current in either direction makes the reading go up.*

*You will have to pay for any power you put on the grid..*

*I read posts from one guy who convinced his power co. to install one
of the old antique mechanical meters with the wheel that will actually spin backwards.
Before that, he was paying to put power on the local grid..*

housing.comment:
Are you planning this system to be vehicle mounted? Stationary? Man-portable?

I saw a power consumption figure for a MacBook Pro online: 13.4 Watts.  I put that into my solar spreadsheet for you at 8 hours of use a day. Note that this does not take into account that you would be using an inverter, since I only run DC devices on my solar setups. If you already have an inverter, you should run your laptop from it and get more precise power consumption figures. Otherwise, I would look into any car charger Apple sells, which will be a much more efficient DC-DC converter.

The below configuration is conservative but designed for sunny areas. You should post your location if you want a more accurate calculation. The battery is large enough to run your laptop for 24 hours before it drops below 50%. The solar array can recharge the batteries to full after 8 hours of laptop usage in 2 hours or so of good sun. So in the summer, you could use your laptop a lot more than 8 hours a day.

Here's the result:



**Battery Size Calculation** |	MacBook Pro	
---------|---------|---------
Power consumption |	13.4	Watts
Daily energy usage (8 hours per day) |	107.2	Wh
Max days without sun |	 3	days
Required battery capacity to not drop below 50% |	643.2	Wh
**Required battery capacity @ 12V** |	**53.6 Ah** 


 
**Solar Array Size Calculation** | MacBook Pro w/ 643.2 Wh Battery
---------|---------|---------
Charge from 50% to full:	 | 321.6	Wh
Run your MacBook Pro for 8 hours:	 | 107.2	Wh
Total power generation required per day: | 	428.8	Wh
Hours of sun per day in winter	 | 8	hours
**Size of panel required (assuming panel produces 85% of rated value)** | **63 Watts**


PM me if you plan to build this system and we can discuss the other components!

housing.comment:
Dow sells chemicals and back sheets to 90% of the industry so would not equate that as a value judgement. 

While PPAs are common I would be very leery of unknown company (financing and warranty risks) and more so of untested technology. Solar shingles have not been deployed on any scale leaving a range of problems to solve including fixed azimuth and shading, and now including roofing issues 100x into the mix as integrated into power generation. 

If someone is offering this - a better deal is likely with traditional provider using most cost effective approach (traditional panels). Beyond the big guys, Astrum Solar is large in NE. 

The structure is not too good to be true - residential PPA - but is long term agreement to buy solar power usually at discount to utility power. But, run from solar shingles - they'll cost more and result and in higher PPA rate. 

Source: have worked in solar finance >10 years. 

Good luck.

housing.comment:
Could be part of a bigger problem, could just be seasonable cloudiness. PVWatts is based on a 30-year climate model, so although it's usually a good predictor for what to expect in terms of production, it's not always spot on. Some things to check for:  
   
1. Do you have one big ol inverter mounted to the side of your home? If yes, any error messages being displayed on it? If no, you probably have little microinverters on the back of each solar panel. Contact your solar installer and have them check their status remotely to check if there are any problems.  

2. The solar panels might have accumulated some dust/pollen in the past few months, especially if you have trees nearby. If it's safe to do so, try and get a visual on your array and see if you can find any visible soot. If so, you can wash them down with a hose, or even get up there with a squeegie and some Windex (again, only if you feel it's safe to do so! If not, hopefully your installer has a maintenance plan and they can do it for you).  

3. Speaking of trees, do you notice any shading on the array from trees or other obstructions nearby?

housing.comment:
Apologies in advance. Recycling a post from another thread regarding the same car. 

There has been a lot of discussion regarding the efficiency of this car and its cost but I think those discussions run counter to what Toyota is trying to achieve by developing this car. Furthermore, cost-wise, it seems to me to be about right for an extremely limited "beta-type" introduction of a new vehicle. Frankly, I'm kinda' surprised that it's not more expensive! Remember when the original [Tesla Roadster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Roadster) was sold in 2008? It was a tiny two seater with a base price of $109,000 and only had a 200 mile range. How far they've come along! 

At any rate, I think that the point of this car today is to test the ability to operate Hydrogen Fuel Cell batteries in the proverbial "real world" as a means of demonstrating and developing this new way for an EV to get its electricity. 
The reason that I think this car has such a heavy “power-autonomy” angle to it, is because the distribution of electricity is already a major growth impediment for the growth of EVs in a large number of cities and countries. Globally, there are significant capacity problems for distributing larger amounts of electricity and this restricts what we can ever achieve with electric cars. While problems exist both in terms of the transmission as well as the generation of power, the problem is far, far greater on the transmission side of things.


There are only so many amps that can be put “into” and pulled “from” an existing infrastructure that has been built upon a standard 3 phase, 600 volt service model. That describes almost every modern city today. Just think about what happens every time temperatures start to consistently reach 100 degrees in most major cities. We run into transmission over-capacity problems due to the increase in A/C demand. Note, during these brown-out / black-out situations, it's almost never a problem on the generation side, it's a problem with the distribution/transmission of power. Where A/C demand is typically 110/120 Volt and only 10- 15 amps, most EVs rely on 240 volt, 30 – 40 amp service, so there is an absolute limit to how many could ever be installed in our current world. We'd bring down the entire system if a large number of people were to suddenly start driving electric cars within our current infrastructure. 

Having said all of that, an overall goal of switching to EVs is to of course to eliminate fossil fuel usage remains a key focus area for us. To achieve the goal we need to build new kinds of infrastructure to replace fossil fuel distribution for ICEs with something that energizes EVs. If we were to look only at electricity management in its current form, it's a huge problem to overcome. There are massive restrictions that prevent us from just adding thousands of additional power lines and building thousands more transformer sub-stations or Power Plants, Solar Arrays, Wind Farms etc. 


To illustrate the scope of the problem, just think for a moment about how excited we get in this subreddit about the success of Tesla. Even though we want to see everybody driving one, [Tesla “hopes” to sell 52,000 cars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Motors) this year, while the country overall will purchase [18,240,000 ICE vehicles in just this year alone](http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/total-vehicle-sales). We barely have the infrastructure to energize beyond a few percent of the overall quantity and that's just looking at "new" vehicles. Today, we have [254,000,000 ICE Vehicles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passenger_vehicles_in_the_United_States) and approximately [373,000 EVs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicles_in_the_United_States) vehicles currently operating in the US. So, 0.0014% of the current registered vehicles today are EVs.
 
So, *THIS* is the underlying reason that I welcome the exploration and development of alternative methods of energizing EVs. Toyota is testing a bold idea here. Maybe it will work and maybe it won't? Maybe it will work in Europe, but not here? Who knows? Regardless, I believe that they are addressing an important and often overlooked problem. We MUST figure out new methods of getting power to EVs if we ever hope to make more significant inroads into the broader passenger vehicle market.

housing.comment:
>Imagine the same technology on individual houses or even shared between a whole village.

I have.  I worked for five years to try to bring solar power plus storage to an off grid community.  In the end, it just wouldn't pencil (this was last year).  We bought diesel generators instead.  Even before the price of oil dropped, it was the cheaper route.

>How economical is it to set up a nuclear power plants for villages and small towns to use.

At this point, not very.  The goal is to build out infrastructure, so smaller scale generation is where we should start.

>First to lay the structure out to the villages and secondly for the villages to be able to afford the power. These places would benefit much better from solar or wind even if the power is intermittent.

Some power, even intermittent power, is better than no power.  Intermittent power allows for charging cell phones and water to be pumped for storage, and even septic systems.  That's huge.  However, that won't allow for household refrigeration, washing machines, lighting, or reliable cooking.  In the poorest areas, the majority of disease still comes from cooking indoors over open fires.  Thus, these places need some stable energy.  Mini-grid infrastructure is a requirement.  From there, small-ish diesel, natural gas, or propane generators are the easiest and cheapest methods to produce the kinds of power these places need.  You might be interested in Hans Rosling's TED talk on why washing machines are so critical to the advancement of poor villages: http://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_and_the_magic_washing_machine?language=en

Beyond that, stable power is needed for any sort of commercial or light industrial purpose, which would give the villages the economic growth needed to pay for all of the above.

housing.comment: The energy mix in Asia is mostly coal, and Asia is where most PV is manufactured. Thus there is a large CO2 imbalance embedded in solar PV made in Asia. Not so much that it can't be overcome during the 25+ year lifetime of the PV. *But* if year after year you are manufacturing more PV's then the year before, that imbalance never catches up! That is the key point - so long as coal is used to make PV, it can't be manufactured too fast otherwise the net effect is to *add* CO2 to the atmosphere. The maths are explained in the article. The solutions are multiple: make solar PV using cleaner energy, or slow down the pace of manufacture if you must use dirty power. Both solutions will add to the cost of solar PV so they are unlikely to happen anytime soon. As consumers the best thing we can do is buy panels made in the US or Europe where the energy mix is cleaner.

housing.comment:
>...and I pointed out that nothing is certain and that it's mind-boggling that "skeptics" demand certainty!

Ah, I see.  You took what one person said and generalized it to all skeptics.  Score one logical fallacy for you.

>Unfortunately, you don't seem to be getting the clue. I'm waiting for you to provide a bloody reference.

I'm sure you can ask your pal John for a paper he co-authored that cites it.  I'm not going to dig it up because, as I already said twice, it's irrelevant to this discussion.  I'm accepting your position on that item for the sake of argument.

>That is an incredibly bold statement...

Here we go.  You can't defend your claim that mitigation is cheaper, so you say, "Nuh, uh.  You are."  Try this.  Cite something that shows that mitigation is undisputably cheaper than adaptation.

>What do you mean by "settled" here? How can a future cost ever be settled?

Exactly, so how can you make the unequivocal statement that mitigation is absolutely, positively cheaper than adaptation.

>That's simply not true. Go have a look at the Stern review and you will see.

You are saying the Stern review is gospel?  When was it written?  2005?  What has happened to estimates of ECS and TCR in the literature since then?  Since I'm sure you'll lie again, I'll tell you.  Estimates of both have decreased since that review was written, both in AR5 and subsequent literature.  You know it's true, so don't bother disputing it.

>That's complete nonsense. 

Do yourself a favor and read what economists have written on the subject.  It's widely acknowledged as a regressive tax.  

>Every tax can be implemented in such a way that it doesn't increase the income gap.

No.  Just no.  A rebate is an attempt to mitigate the regressive tax.  That doesn't make the tax *not* regressive.

>No, I haven't. The average citizien doesn't even know what "intermittent" means.

Are we talking about skeptics or the masses?  You know very well that skeptics know the meaning of intermittency.  

>Nonsense. Renewables are competitive entirely without subsidies as soon as they are rolled out sufficiently.

You are so deluded:

[Total federal subsidies in fiscal year 2007 were $24.34 per megawatt hour for solar-generated electricity and $23.37 per megawatt hour for wind, compared with $1.59 for nuclear, $0.67 for hydroelectric power, $0.44 for conventional coal, and $0.25 for natural gas and petroleum liquids.  **In fiscal year 2010, the subsidies were even higher. For solar power, they were $775.64 per megawatt hour, for wind $56.29, for nuclear $3.14**, for hydroelectric power $0.82, for coal $0.64 and for natural gas and petroleum liquids $0.64.](http://instituteforenergyresearch.org/hard-facts-basic-energy-facts/)

Maybe tell Jim Hansen that he's wrong about nuclear while you are in a bullshtting mood.

> How is it actually fair to demand that a utility buy your energy above the wholesale rate?

This. People who make a lot of passive income look for ways to reduce how much they'll have to pay in taxes on that income. housing.comment: Great question, although winter does have shorter days and a little more cloud cover, we also had a large oak tree to the south of the house that blocked some of the array during winter when the sun moved far enough south for those winter months. Our solar installer had informed us of this, and the system was built to be just large enough (but not to large because of Florida's solar buy back policy -it does not exist) to get us through with a stored KWH credit bank until the power company resets the meter on Jan 1st. However, the tree is down now, although we didn't take it down because of the solar panels - the cost to take an oak down would never make up for what little more we would need- it was just old and snapped during a spring storm this year. That said, I expect that if I was to post this again next year there would be a lot less of a dip, and maybe I would not have a bill during the winter at all. Side note, in the oaks place, we planted several smaller trees that are local to the region that feed the birds/bees/wildlife, they just will not get large enough to block the panels again, but we did make sure to get something back in place that gives back to mother nature as well.

housing.comment:
> The half a billion dollar tax dollar sink that mislead the fed about their own prospects to receive said loans  does not inspire confidence.

If you had read the article I posted you would have realized that actually the US government MADE MONEY off the overall loan program Solyndra was a part of, because by and large, the companies who applied for the loans were legitimate, actually conducted valuable research, and paid us back with interest. So your ramblings about money are a non sequitir, because again, WE MADE MONEY ON THE PROGRAM OVERALL. 

Here’s the thing about research. It’s really hard to do in the private sector. Not saying it can’t be done. Perkins and Will for example is a private firm that does research on sustainable tech. But overall it is a risky and hard business. So there is a push and pull with the government playing a role. I’m more than okay with government funded research, especially if it’s turning a profit for the government. If some of it fails that’s okay too. That’s the nature of research. 

> the cheapest electric car costing $25k

I’m in agreement that EV’s continue to be a difficult roll out. That said, in five minutes I was able to find a used Leaf for $10k. So you are overstating cost a bit here by not taking the used market into consideration.

I believe the tech for EV’s to be totally viable is about 10 years away. However if you live on the right land, you could install solar panels on your roof today and they’d pay for themselves within 10 years. That’s the other part of the equation you miss. The upfront cost is high, no doubt there. But the long term cost actually comes in lower. And then when you start adding in tax breaks, it becomes more affordable. 

> if we had reliable battery tech that could power a home for a month 

I have personally met engineers who have built closed solar systems for small (mostly private) islands that run entirely off solar energy. There is no back up. The battery technology is there today if you have the space to put them somewhere. The capability is not the problem; the space is the problem. The space issue gets better every year. The next ten years we are going to see a lot of maturation of this technology and I expect the costs will continue to drop as they have been for some time now.

housing.comment:
Others have good answers on the car question; I'm of the opinion that if you just want to jet around a little for the tasks mentioned almost anything works. Ok, maybe not a Smart4Two EV but what do I know... an older used Leaf might be a particularly cheap option if your needed range is short.

On the solar question I'm a little behind as my array went up back in 2005; I'm also grid-tied but on grid 50 so I almost never have an outage. I think the below is still accurate(-ish):

You sell power to PG&E during the day. It's bought at not the best rate, but eh, that's PG&E. This gives you credits that true-up for power produced versus used, where the price for your used is based on the time of day price - and that's part of the package you have with PG&E.

So say you sell back to PG&E during the day, produce 20 kWh per day and maybe they pay 8c/kWh to you. You then buy back mostly at night for 8c/kWh and see what the difference is. You may consume 3-4 kWh during the day at a higher rate, but if you keep the majority of the consumption at night it kind of evens out or maybe even leaves you with a surplus.

(Numbers specious and purely used for example).

At the end of the time period you have a true-up; mine's yearly, but you may have monthly instead. It's all based on the deal you signed with AT&T and it should be called out in that documentation.

IIRC there are different plans for a plain EV owner versus someone who just has solar panels; I don't recall anything about the two combined.

housing.comment:
> From an emissions perspective I would like to see zero new ICEs sold. 

I agree with you entirely on this. This is why I don't like PHEVs on principal (along with cost and maintenance) – they are a product that never should have existed had manufacturers made a proper investment in battery tech in the first place. 

If 100kWh batteries and 150kW charging were standard (and affordable), we'd see a much higher rate of adoption. For the time being, neither of those things are true, as they're expensive and rare... but I think we're inching closer to that goal. Plus, infrastructure.

Don't get me wrong – I acknowledge the places where carbon emissions are bad. I've been hoping to see general aviation (and later, commercial aviation) turn more to renewables. There are strides being made in single-engine, battery-electric aircraft being produced as trainers that will cost a very small fraction of gasoline (leaded fuel, at that) aircraft to power and maintain. I've got 350+ hours in small aircraft burning 8+ gallons an hour of leaded Avgas, and that's probably among my single worst contributions to the environment. So, that's why we put more miles on our EV than on an ICE car. We had hoped to get solar and battery storage but have *just* enough tree coverage to make it not viable for our specific townhome – even though our next door neighbors are in full sun. We do [pay extra on our energy bill](https://sonomacleanpower.org/programs/evergreen) to use almost all renewable energy, however.

I actually have a similar situation but not as good as yours.  I don't get 1:1 for net metering but instead I get about 1/3 the return for every kWh sent out.

I have 2 LG RESU10H batteries and generate enough energy so that I'm good even without the batteries (wish I didn't spend the money on them), at least for now.  In a couple years, I don't klnow with a growing family.

Because of potential increase in teenagers in the home in a couple of years plus degradation, I was wondering what would be the best in just preserving the battery for that time. housing.comment:
East vs West makes no difference at all for total production (actually, east probably produces more as it's colder in the morning). All south facing (if you live in the northern hemisphere) is the best overall, and ideally the incline based on your latitude. 

But you want extra west typically because that gets you more power in the hot part of the day when you run A/C, and makes it easier to consume what you produce and limit your exports. Depending on your net metering agreement, it may or may not matter.

housing.comment:
Yeah I am a City Manager in Ohio and rooftop solar on houses would be awful for the city and residents. Usually municipal power have contracts and a diverse portfolio of power sources (own 0.5% of 200 sources...) and you're on the hook for buying that power. If 10% of homes were suddenly powered by solar... we're still buying that power through the lifetime of the debt on the source. And net metering isnt a good deal because we're selling back to the grid at less than the power we're already buying and not using. Basically municipal systems don't get net metering, so homes here can't.

If the federal government wanted to be as green as they could be, they'd buy up the debt of existing hydro and coal facilities to 1) take coal out, and 2) free up purchasing power to invest in better forms of energy. But it's not sexy because it doesn't create jobs *immediately*.

housing.comment:
Seconding this nuanced take. It can be quite difficult to give great advice without several factors (electricity price, net metering policy, usage profile, house orientation/shading issues, purchase method, resale values in your area). Not all of those are always clear when you first move in. 

As a single point anecdotal, I'm in Texas. My payback period was 8 years when I had 1:1 net metering. Now it's 10-11 years following net metering plan changes. That's with relatively cheap electricity that's been pretty stable in cost. 

In my area, realtors I know see solar as value neutral. Doesn't add to the price of the home for most buyers. Doesn't subtract from it either for most buyers. There is a subset of people that it would add or subtract for, but as crazy as the housing market is, you're more likely to get a cash offer from someone who doesn't care and it's worth the simplified sale quickly. People looking for a deal on solar are already cost conscious and will be looking for better deals on housing anyway. Which makes sense to me as a cheapskate who paid for solar once already.

food.comment:
I've met tons of people. Yes, some people are fat because they eat poorly.. i've met some of those too.. plenty. but not everyone. i have a friend who's vegan and pretty heavy- she works out before and after every meal (and i mean some serious workout she got from a military friend).. she works 12 hour shifts on her feet then goes homes and jogs (she's insane!). Contrarily, I have a friend who spent an entire summer eating as much horrible junk food as she could and sitting on the couch in an attempt to gain weight- she didn't. she got all the way up to 107lbs dripping wet. 

People do have different body types- different metabolisms, different chemical makeups, etc and that doesn't even take into account eating disorders or medical issues- being an ass to fat people just because they don't look how you want them too does *not* make you a good person. 

edit: the blogger even SAID she exercises every day as well as having mental health issues.. and you're going to be an ass about it? really?

food.comment:
That's a lot statements that warrant responses so I'll just start at the top.

I said we don't generally euthanize humans because you suggested I go to my local hospital's neo-natal unit *where they don't euthanize babies* and suggest this to them. They don't euthanize humans so I won't suggest that to them. There are many problems that someone could have with this other than the indignity. I only gave you three. This method is only used on **piglets.** If I'm terminally ill and can decide on my own method of euthanasia, I'm too old for this method. I would not be smashed repeatedly either. It's one quick blow to the head. In the video you'll see piglets moving after the slam, but that is just muscle spasms. They are dead I promise you.

Veterinarians don't use this method because most people don't have piglets with congenital defects. An old cat or dog has developed past the point where this method is acceptable.

[The fact is that manually applied blunt force trauma to the head, either with an implement or by striking the head against a surface, has been shown to cause immediate unconsciousness and rapid death when performed correctly on **young** piglets.](http://atwork.avma.org/2012/07/21/hot-on-facebook-euthanasia-of-suckling-pigs-using-blunt-force-trauma/)

From the same source.

>Physical methods of euthanasia (e.g., blunt force trauma, gunshot, decapitation) can be disturbing to observers, even when expertly performed. Because of this, it makes sense to consider alternatives if observers are unprepared or may be distressed by witnessing this type of euthanasia.

That is another reason vets would opt to use other means of euthanasia.

What "ridiculous statement" are you talking about? I don't say these things to be a troll. I believe these things, but I'll admit that unfortunately the discussions often devolve into arguments over semantics. I had an interesting conversation that didn't. Did you see that one? 

I don't mind vegans so long as they don't mind me. I saw [this](http://www.reddit.com/r/vegan/comments/13d44x/would_it_be_ethical_to_make_a_vaccine_to_render/) post when I "discovered' this subreddit and it troubled me. I decided to use this account to try and be the other side so that discussions like those don't end up one-sided. 

I didn't make a ridiculous post here to bother people. I'm trying to clarify that blunt force trauma is quick and painless when used to euthanize piglets with congenital defects. I didn't want an argument. [Once again](http://atwork.avma.org/2012/07/21/hot-on-facebook-euthanasia-of-suckling-pigs-using-blunt-force-trauma/) for those who missed it.

food.comment:
Aww nawitus :(

Since I really enjoyed your posts on the urban decay thread since they were so well thought out and, in my view at least, unbiased. So I figured I'd come back to this and explain that post a bit more since its clear you're actually rational.

I didn't mean philosophy as if I thought there was some kind of theological background to a paleo diet. I'm currently studying nutrition because of doing crossfit and wanting to get the most out of it while remaining vegan. Anyways, in the class each diet is represented with a food pyramid and a list of facts.

So vegan says "no animal products including those for insects (ie. milk, eggs, honey)"
And gluten free might say something like "avoids wheat, rye, barley, and oats (note: oats are gluten free but are grown in the same fields as wheat, rye, and barley so cross contamination is high)"

Each of these are called a "dietary philosophy" to help everyone learn the fundamentals of every kind of diet. Everything I said was based on comparing a healthy vegan diet to a healthy paleo diet while avoiding all my bias as a vegan, because I don't think my personal beliefs about how wrong it is to take an animal's life for food will suddenly sway their opinion... But maybe showing the similarities between the two from a dietary standpoint would? A guy can dream I suppose...

About the processed food I didn't mean for it to sound like I meant all vegans avoid processed foods because I would never take it upon myself to speak for all vegans. I was only talking about healthy diets which should all avoid heavily processed foods as much as they can. Even now I have a block of cheddar daiya in my fridge so I'm not saying it's the basis of veganism. I won't buy any more of it because of the palm oil, I've also started making my own cheese from homemade yogurt (cashew with a coconut milk starter) which makes me rely less on the store bought stuff :)

But again, just thought I'd reply since I consider you one of the more interesting and rational posters on here. I was trying to do the same but clearly I failed somewhere along the line. :/

food.comment:
It really depends on the context, whether you're willing to further alienate these people (because no matter what you say, if you push it that's always a risk), and how deep you want to get into it.

Here are some responses I might give:

“Well, meat may be bad for me, but we’ve all got to die of something, might as well be happy while we’re alive.” **Yes, we'll all eventually die, but whether we die healthy or after many years of suffering from health problems is based on the lifestyle choices we make now. I'd rather not be in a wheelchair and diapers for the last decade of my life, and the food I eat tastes just as good as what I used to eat/what you eat, so I'm not any less happy now. Its a win-win. As a future nurse I'd think you'd want to prevent unnecessary diseases and medical care. You know, so we can spend more time on the people who really care about their lives.** or something sarcastic like "that's so true, wanna go do some heroin?"

“Sucks to be them.” **That's really sad, and not very compassionate or empathic. I'm glad people didn't say that about slaves or Holocaust victims. If that was everyone's attitude the world would be a really shitty place. As a future nurse I'd think you'd have more compassion for the suffering of others.** - Note: I realize this is a bold and insulting thing to say, so obviously I would only use it if I really didn't care if the other person hated me after I said it. 

“Tell you the truth, if someone told me I would die tomorrow from eating meat, I’d go out for a cheeseburger. Gotta live while you’re alive.” **I ate a veggie burger with vegan cheese last night. It was delicious and it won't give me heart disease or cancer. And this (insert delicious vegan food here) I had the other day was incredible. You don't have to sacrifice taste to be healthy or to care about animals and the environment.**

food.comment:
Lean meat obviously isn't vegan. But I'm not going to accuse someone of not being vegan just because they occasionally eat lean meat, especially when they know they shouldn't. That's splitting hairs in my book as well. 

It would be kind of like accusing my dad of being a smoker because he'll have a cigar at events from time to time. The reality is that he used to actually be a pack a day smoker and quit. Trying to say that an occasional cigar makes him a smoker would be splitting hairs. I view veganism in a similar light, it involves trying to quit something that can be hard to avoid at times, often due in large part by social situations. I don't expect perfection, especially not with veganism, as avoiding every instance of animal exploitation would be virtually impossible. Drawing a line for the vegan label over the occasional slip when we live in a society that's constantly pushing it in your face seems a tad anal. Especially so when you start to consider all our other sins against animals that don't involve utilizing their bodies.

food.comment:
The more comfortable and confident you become in yourself and how you choose to eat, the more they will be comfortable around you.  At least that's what my experience has been with my family.  Actually my sister became a vegan after I was vegetarian for over 8 years, my ways rubbed off on her!  I no longer live with my parents whom both still eat meat, but they always respected my choice to go vegetarian greatly and loved when I cooked meals for them, they would also eat veg several times a week (I'm currently trying to quit cheese and whey protein! although I've been vegan for a number of years before).  

As for friends, I don't keep too many meat eating close friends simply because killing is something I avoid on a deeply personal level.  That's not to say I don't respect omnivores and am not friendly with co-workers and family who eat meat, but when it comes to whom I spend my time with and confide in, they are vegetarian and vegan because they have a heart humane enough not to kill, indirect or direct.  

It's my resolve deep within my heart that makes people naturally respect the way I eat and feel more than comfortable being around me eating meals.  They can see it's not some passing phase or that I feel undecided or awkward that I'm not eating animal products like they are.  

This does not mean I have always been shown respect for how I eat, no I've had my challenges.  In fact one time at a job I was working someone took deep offense when he found out I was a vegetarian.  I quickly learned how to explain the reason for not eating meat so as not to offend certain people.

Anyways just thought I'd share my own experience.  But I will say you reach a point where this doesn't even phase you, if one even encounters this negative support at all.  

It sounds like it's coming from right in your household and is going to be a challenge.  You will also come to learn who truly respects you regardless of how or what you choose to eat.  You also have to have understanding and patience, some people may respect you but simply struggle personally to understand why someone wouldn't eat like them, the most important thing is not to make people feel like you look down on how they eat, everyone deserves respect.

food.comment:
I was vegetarian for 10 years before I became fully vegan.

My vegan diet came through no conscious decision, it was a slow transition which I did not engineer. I must have stopped eating eggs and milk at least 5 or 6 years ago, I almost never bought cheese throughout my 10 years of vegetarianism. 

I wasn't a good vegetarian. I ate ramen noodles (ones which were devoid of chicken or beef stock ext), rice with soy sauce and pasta as my staples. I lived on a shoe-string budget because I'm not a very wealthy individual. I'm pretty lucky that I don't have excessive needs. Sweet foods like chocolate and other dairy confectionery were never things that I liked to eat.

Gradually, I came to realize that my diet was actually vegan. My realization came at a time when I moved into an apartment without refrigeration. I couldn't keep milk or dairy products which I seldom purchased prior to living in my new apartment.

I really changed when I decided to make the switch to actual and conscious veganism. It came at the same time that I started running, exercising, studying and reading better material. 

I'd never felt healthier than when when I made the switch to a vegan diet which featured soy milk, tofu, supplements, fresh and canned fruit, fresh vegetables ext. 

I've been fully and actively vegan for around 5 years. The total time of veganism and vegetarianism is about 15 years. I don't think that I can ever look back from veganism. Having a healthy diet has given me a healthy body. A healthy body and mind are intrinsically linked.

> A couple circumstances that would make arguing diet inappropriate are: history of eating disorders, digestive tract issues (chrohns disease), access to food whether geographical or financial. food.comment:
There are some vitamins, such as B12, that vegans should pay more attention to, and some that non-vegans should pay more attention to. These things can easily be supplemented if someone feels their diet puts them at risk of deficiency (although, an appropriately planned diet that meets one's nutritional needs on its own is always a good option too).

Meat is considered a luxury by most of the world's poor. Foods like beans, rice, peanuts, cassava, lentils, and cereals are staples of the world's poor, and we see lots of examples of cheap and flavorful foods incorporating these things in Ethiopian or Indian cuisine, as just a couple examples.

food.comment:
So I can understand that B12, Iron and Omega 3 are harder to get on a vegan diet. And if you aren't careful with it then you can have less than ideal levels.

However, I don't see how this would lead to you being more likely to get ill with, say, a common cold. B12 relates to nerves and brain function, Omega 3 relates to heart health and blood pressure, Iron relates to your ability to carry oxygen in the blood. I guess Iron could be relatable, as fewer healthy red blood cells might make fighting illnesses more difficult; though I'm no doctor. 

Hope that makes sense where I'm coming from. Like I say though, I'm no doctor so perhaps someone can chip in who knows a bit more!

food.comment:
I don't know Strasbourg specifically but I'm French. You can try r/vegFR if you want to find a vegan Strasbourgeois.

Use the HappyCow and Vegoresto apps to know where the vegan restaurants are. There are usually a few in each big French cities, even if it is less common than in Germany. Lebanese restaurants are also a good way to eat tasty and cheap(ish) accidentally vegan food.

Regular supermarkets do not have a great selection of vegan products but it has gotten slightly better over the years. You will be luckier in big supermarkets (hypermarchés) or Monoprix. Organic stores (like BioCoop, Naturalia, La Vie Claire...) usually have a decent selection of vegan products: it might be expensive sometimes but basic products like tofu are accessible. You can also try to find an Asian supermarket for inexpensive tofu, tempeh or other vegan staples.

I go to a Christian school and environmental science is a required course here. The professor asked the class of about 85 people who was vegetarian. One person raised their hand. food.comment:
You are making an argument against doing what is biologically necessary for a cat. The burden of proof is on you. If you want to see my arguments and posts of scientific journals to continue your research, I mean actually want to, you can click on my user and search through the comments. I have argued this on the sub many times and no one, no one who has disagreed has ever bothered to give me a sound argument besides, "That's what a carnist would say." 

I struggled with this concept when I turned vegan for a long time. I put in the work. I read for forever. I came to the conclusion that feeding cats a vegan diet is wrong. I genuinely would love for someone to prove those hours of research wrong and I mean that.

food.comment:
Well, maybe I'm being spiteful, but we own a (truly) vegan business which happens to be in direct competition with another that is owned and operated by omnivores. The other business's employees have been absolute assholes to us, and even though we've ignored absolutely everything they've thrown our way, we're wondering if it's time to call them out. 

The other business has talked shit about our chef's ability to cook, our use of biodiesel in our cars, and has lied several times about their ingredients. They continually prod us on Facebook and it really grinds our gears to see them continually talking up veganism, criticizing OUR ethics, and trying to promote themselves as some bastion of the philosophy, when their only interest in the topic lies in the pay it provides.
